diseases.name: giardiasis
diseases.description: Giardiasis is an intestinal infection caused by the parasite Giardia lamblia (also known as Giardia duodenalis or Giardia intestinalis). It is one of the most common waterborne parasitic infections worldwide.
diseases.transmission: Contaminated water, person-to-person contact, contaminated food, poor sanitation, recreational water activities
diseases.severity: Usually mild to moderate, can become chronic if untreated
diseases.treatment: Metronidazole (flagyl), tinidazole, nitazoxanide, albendazole. Treatment duration typically 5-10 days. Supportive care with fluid replacement.
diseases.prevention: Boil water for 1 minute, avoid swallowing recreational water, practice good hand hygiene, avoid ice from unknown sources, peel fruits yourself
diseases.region_specific_info: Common during monsoon season in Northeast India. Higher risk in areas with poor sanitation. Available treatment at district hospitals and PHCs.

diseases.name: cryptosporidiosis
diseases.description: Cryptosporidiosis is a diarrheal disease caused by microscopic parasites of the genus Cryptosporidium. It can cause severe dehydration and is particularly dangerous for immunocompromised individuals.
diseases.transmission: Contaminated water, swimming pools, contaminated food, person-to-person contact, animal contact
diseases.severity: Mild to severe, potentially life-threatening in immunocompromised patients
diseases.treatment: Nitazoxanide for immunocompetent patients. Supportive care with oral rehydration therapy. No specific treatment for immunocompromised patients - focus on immune system support.
diseases.prevention: Boil water before drinking, avoid swallowing pool/lake water, wash hands frequently, avoid contact with infected animals, practice food safety
diseases.region_specific_info: Resistance to chlorine makes it persistent in water supplies. Outbreaks reported during monsoon in Northeast India. Seek immediate medical attention if symptoms persist.

diseases.name: shigellosis
diseases.description: Shigellosis is an infectious disease caused by Shigella bacteria. It primarily affects the large intestine and causes severe diarrhea, often with blood and mucus.
diseases.transmission: Contaminated water, person-to-person contact, contaminated food, poor sanitation, flies carrying bacteria
diseases.severity: Moderate to severe, can cause complications like hemolytic uremic syndrome
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics (ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, ceftriaxone), fluid replacement therapy, avoid anti-diarrheal medications
diseases.prevention: Safe drinking water, hand hygiene, proper food handling, improved sanitation, fly control measures
diseases.region_specific_info: Endemic in Northeast India with seasonal peaks during monsoon. Higher transmission in crowded areas. Treatment available at government health facilities.

diseases.name: campylobacteriosis
diseases.description: Campylobacteriosis is one of the most common bacterial causes of gastroenteritis, caused by Campylobacter jejuni and other Campylobacter species.
diseases.transmission: Contaminated water, undercooked poultry, unpasteurized milk, contaminated food, contact with infected animals
diseases.severity: Usually self-limiting, but can cause serious complications like Guillain-Barr√© syndrome
diseases.treatment: Usually self-limiting. Antibiotics (erythromycin, azithromycin, fluoroquinolones) for severe cases or high-risk patients. Supportive care with fluids.
diseases.prevention: Cook poultry thoroughly, pasteurized dairy products, safe water, hand hygiene, avoid cross-contamination
diseases.region_specific_info: Common in rural areas of Northeast India. Associated with backyard poultry farming. Seasonal increase during warm months.

diseases.name: amoebiasis
diseases.description: Amoebiasis is an infection caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. It can cause both intestinal and extraintestinal complications.
diseases.transmission: Contaminated water, contaminated food, person-to-person contact, poor sanitation
diseases.severity: Can range from asymptomatic to severe with life-threatening complications
diseases.treatment: Metronidazole followed by paromomycin or iodoquinol to eliminate cysts. Treatment duration 7-10 days for tissue infection plus luminal agent.
diseases.prevention: Safe drinking water, proper sanitation, hand hygiene, avoid raw vegetables in endemic areas, food safety measures
diseases.region_specific_info: Endemic in Northeast India with higher prevalence in rural areas. Liver abscess complications require specialized treatment at district/medical college hospitals.

diseases.name: rotavirus_infection
diseases.description: Rotavirus is the leading cause of severe diarrhea among infants and young children worldwide. It causes significant morbidity and mortality in developing countries.
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral route, contaminated water, contaminated surfaces, person-to-person contact
diseases.severity: Can be severe in children under 5 years, leading to severe dehydration and death if untreated
diseases.treatment: Supportive care with oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, continued feeding. No specific antiviral treatment available.
diseases.prevention: Rotavirus vaccination, safe water, hand hygiene, breastfeeding, improved sanitation
diseases.region_specific_info: Major cause of childhood diarrhea in Northeast India. Vaccination available under government immunization program. Peak season during cooler months.

diseases.name: norovirus_infection
diseases.description: Norovirus is a highly contagious virus that causes gastroenteritis. It is often called the 'winter vomiting bug' and can cause large outbreaks.
diseases.transmission: Contaminated water, contaminated food, person-to-person contact, contaminated surfaces, airborne transmission
diseases.severity: Usually mild and self-limiting, but can cause severe dehydration in vulnerable populations
diseases.treatment: Supportive care with fluid replacement, oral rehydration therapy. No specific antiviral treatment. Avoid dairy and fatty foods initially.
diseases.prevention: Hand hygiene, safe water, proper food handling, surface disinfection, isolation of infected individuals
diseases.region_specific_info: Outbreaks common in schools and communities in Northeast India. Highly infectious - strict hygiene measures needed. Usually resolves in 1-3 days.

diseases.name: escherichia_coli_infection
diseases.description: E. coli infection, particularly by enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) and enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC), is a major cause of traveler's diarrhea and childhood diarrhea.
diseases.transmission: Contaminated water, undercooked meat, contaminated vegetables, person-to-person contact
diseases.severity: Usually mild to moderate, but some strains like E. coli O157:H7 can cause severe complications
diseases.treatment: Supportive care with fluids. Antibiotics usually not recommended as they may increase toxin production. Oral rehydration therapy essential.
diseases.prevention: Safe water, proper food handling, cook meat thoroughly, wash vegetables, hand hygiene
diseases.region_specific_info: Common cause of traveler's diarrhea in Northeast India. Street food consumption increases risk. Avoid antibiotics unless specifically indicated.

diseases.name: salmonellosis
diseases.description: Salmonellosis is a foodborne and waterborne illness caused by Salmonella bacteria (non-typhoidal). It causes gastroenteritis and can lead to bacteremia.
diseases.transmission: Contaminated water, contaminated food (especially eggs, poultry, meat), person-to-person contact, contact with infected animals
diseases.severity: Usually self-limiting, but can cause severe illness in immunocompromised individuals
diseases.treatment: Supportive care with fluids. Antibiotics only for severe cases or high-risk patients (ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, ceftriaxone).
diseases.prevention: Safe food handling, cook eggs and meat thoroughly, pasteurized products, safe water, hand hygiene
diseases.region_specific_info: Endemic in Northeast India with seasonal peaks. Associated with consumption of contaminated water and street food. Avoid unnecessary antibiotic use.

diseases.name: viral_gastroenteritis
diseases.description: Viral gastroenteritis, often called 'stomach flu', is inflammation of the stomach and intestines caused by various viruses including adenovirus, astrovirus, and sapovirus.
diseases.transmission: Contaminated water, person-to-person contact, contaminated food, poor hygiene
diseases.severity: Usually mild and self-limiting, lasting 1-3 days
diseases.treatment: Supportive care with oral rehydration therapy, rest, gradual return to normal diet. No specific antiviral treatment available.
diseases.prevention: Hand hygiene, safe water, avoid close contact with infected individuals, surface disinfection
diseases.region_specific_info: Common during monsoon and winter months in Northeast India. Often spreads rapidly in schools and communities. Most cases resolve without medical intervention.

prevention_tips.tip_text: Always boil water for at least 1 minute before drinking, especially during monsoon season
Wash hands with soap and clean water for at least 20 seconds before eating and after using toilet
Avoid raw or undercooked meat, fish, and eggs
Do not swallow water while swimming in lakes, rivers, or pools
Get vaccinated for rotavirus (children) and hepatitis A as recommended
Store cooked food at proper temperatures and consume within 2 hours
Use oral rehydration solution (ORS) immediately if diarrhea starts
Maintain proper toilet hygiene and sewage disposal systems
Avoid street food and water from unknown sources, especially during travel
Disinfect surfaces regularly, especially in households with infected individuals

emergency_contacts.regional_info: Contact nearest Primary Health Centre (PHC) or Community Health Centre (CHC) for immediate medical attention
